H0.text: What is the common term for the practice of freezing a human body in hope of a cure being developed enabling thawing and revival. Cryotherapy

H1.text: What is the common term for the practice of freezing a human body in hope of a cure being developed enabling thawing and revival. Cryopreservation

H2.text: What is the common term for the practice of freezing a human body in hope of a cure being developed enabling thawing and revival. Suspended Animation

H3.text: What is the common term for the practice of freezing a human body in hope of a cure being developed enabling thawing and revival. Cryonic

A4.text: Cryonics is the low-temperature freezing and storage of human remains in the hope that resurrection may be possible in the future.

A5.text: Cryopreservation is accomplished by freezing with or without cryoprotectant to reduce ice damage, or by vitrification to avoid ice damage.

A6.text: Cryopreservation was applied to human materials beginning in 1954 with three pregnancies resulting from the insemination of previously frozen sperm.

A7.text: The first human corpse to be frozen with the hope of future resurrection was James Bedford's, a few hours after his cancer-caused death in 1967.

A8.text: Cryotherapy is a specific type of low-temperature treatment used to reduce inflammation and its associated pain.

A9.text: Cryotherapy can be used in many ways, including whole-body exposure for therapeutic health benefits, or locally to treat a variety of tissue lesions.

A10.text: Cryonics could eventually provide long-term suspended animation.

A11.text: Suspended animation is understood as the pausing of life processes by external or internal means without terminating life itself.
